results.title: The Picture of Dorian Gray
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Pandro S. Berman and Albert Lewin
results.brief_description: The picture of Dorian Gray is a superb film based on Oscar Wilde’s novel about a young man who wishes that his portrait could age while he remains youthful. The portrait does grow old, showing not only Dorian Gray’s age but also the sins and aberrations of his wicked life. Dorian remains handsome, young and seemingly uncorrupted by his own decadence. Stars George Sanders, Hurd Hatfield, Donna Reed, Angela Lansbury and Peter Lawford.

results.title: The Picture gallery
results.brief_description: Intrinsic in many great paintings is a sense of movement. Rather than seeming static, the figures appear to be caught in motion. A young Czech animator, Jan Trmal, has taken ten such paintings and by separating their elements has actually set them in motion for a brief time to the music of Gianfranco Maselli, Antonin Vranicky and Johann S. Bach.

results.title: The Picnic
results.brief_description: A small boy kept in after school finds a notice about a girls’ picnic and shows it to the boys who plan to gate crash. The girls realise this and prepare sandwiches with shoe nugget and drinks with paint. When the boys raid the lunch bags they receive a nasty shock.

results.title: The Pickwick papers. Part 2
results.brief_description: In the chaotic and amusing adventures of Samuel Pickwick and his companions, conviviality and romance abound as a festive and snowy Christmas is spent with Mr Wardle at Dingley Dell. But Pickwick is also in deep trouble over his alleged breach of promise to Mrs Bardell. Outrageous misunderstandings and legal shenanigans result in Pickwick being committed to prison, where the horror of what he sees arouses his inherent goodness and tender humility. This is a colourful BBC adaptation of Charles Dickens first and much loved bestseller.

results.title: The Pickwick papers. Part 1
results.brief_description: As Messrs Pickwick, Topman, Snodgrass and Winkle embark on their uproarious and accident-prone adventures around England, they can’t possibly imagine the mishap and merriment that awaits them. Tricked and compromised by the slippery Mr Jingle, caught in the passionate embrace of true love - as well as the snare of a misguided breach of promise lawsuit, they career through the country from coaching inn to stagecoach, leaving behind an extraordinary trail of hilarity and disaster. Rated: G

results.title: The Piano teacher = La Pianiste [DVD] (E)
results.creator_credit: MK2 Productions, Les Films Alain Sarde, Wega Film, Arte France, Marin Karmitz, Alain Sarde, Veit Heiduschka and Michael Haneke
results.brief_description: Erika Kohut (Isabelle Huppert) is a repressed middle-aged classical piano teacher in Vienna who lives with her demanding, manipulative mother (Annie Girardot). Erika presents a cool, detached aristocratic demeanor to her students and to the world. But she also leads a masochistic private life: she searches for anonymous sex in pornographic theatres, which in turn leads her to self-destructive acts of self-mutilation to assuage her guilt. When a handsome young music student, Walter (Benoit Magimel), attempts to seduce Erika, his forthright masculinity and her own masochistic desires create an untenable situation for the piano teacher. Erika begins to force her mother to acknowledge the incestuous underpinnings of their destructive relationship and she forces Walter to confront a damaged femininity for which he is unprepared. Michael Haneke’s films have all been defined by a cold detached observation of social breakdown. “The Piano teacher”, based on Elfriede Jelinek’s novel, is a powerful and deeply disturbing film. Huppert’s performance is central to the film’s success. It is a performance of deep courage and she creates one of screen history’s most devastating and unrelenting portrayals of feminine masochism. But this is not only a film about individual sexual dysfunction. For Haneke, Erika’s repression and self-disgust is firmly connected to her passion for the rigours and classicism of European music. The Viennese Conservatory in which she teaches becomes a symbol of highly controlled, repressive bourgeois and aristocratic culture, a culture which demands the inhuman vanquishing of contradiction and emotion. This is a bleakly unsettling film which suggests that built into the very foundations of Western “high art” is an oppressive, vigilant surveillance and repression of excess and desire. Obviously, and not unsurprisingly with its Viennese setting, the film shares a deeply Freudian pessimism about the future of culture. This is not an easy film to watch and it contains extremely disturbing images of sexual self-abuse. It is nevertheless a consistent and unforgettable investigation of Western culture at a point of spiritual collapse. And the film is unimaginable without Huppert whose performance allows us to both understand individual suffering and the wider social and political analogies that Haneke wants to draw through her character. Huppert won the Best Actress Award and Magimel won the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival for their performances. The DVD interviews with Haneke and Jelinek are outstanding as is the commentary by Huppert.

results.title: The Piano
results.creator_credit: CiBy 2000, Saddleback Productions, Jan Chapman and Jane Campion
results.brief_description: Jane Campion’s fourth feature is a visually sumptuous and tactile tale of adultery set during the early European colonisation of New Zealand, with Harvey Keitel daringly cast in the role of a passionately romantic lover and Holly Hunter as a woman physically unable to articulate her feelings. Ada McGrath (Hunter) can hear and communicates in sign language through her young daughter, Fiona (Anna Paquin), but she can’t talk. Apart from her child, Ada’s most treasured possession is her piano. She marries a man she’s never met, a pioneer settler (Sam Neill) in New Zealand. The marriage starts badly when Neill refuses to transport Ada’s piano to his settlement. Later, he allows George Baines (Keitel), who has ‘gone native’ to have the piano. Baines then offers to return the piano to Ada - if she gives him piano lessons. These lessons become stages in an increasingly erotic courtship. Campion unfolds this striking story boldly with flashes of unexpected humour. The settlement is chilly, muddy and rainswept, a place where civilisation is barely making an impact. Hunter played solo piano and acted as piano coach on this production. Paquin became one of the youngest actors to receive an Academy Award for her performance. Cast also includes Kerry Walker, Genevieve Lemon.

results.title: The Pianist [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Studio Canal, Roman Polanski, Robert Benmussa and Alain Sarde
results.brief_description: An epic but true tale of the pianist Wladyslaw Szpilman’s struggle as a Polish Jew to survive World War II. Based on a book by Szpilman, Ronald Harwood’s Academy Award winning screenplay covers the period of the second World War. Roman Polanski’s skill in motion picture storytelling is evident here as he is also a winner of the Academy Award for Best Director. The film received seven nominations in all, most notably the Best Actor Award going to Adrien Brody for his portrayal of Szpilman. A gifted composer and pianist, Szpilman was making regular appearances on Polish radio when the Nazis overran Warsaw. His family are taken to the walled Ghetto where Szpilman is able to make a meagre living by playing piano in a cafe where the more affluent and sometimes corrupt Jewish people dine. He narrowly escapes the fate of his family’s trip to the death camps and survives with the help of friends and his own instinct and just pure willpower. A sympathetic German officer who is moved by his talent also spares and sustains his life. A moving portrayal of the plight of Polish Jews but one which also shows that there are good and bad people on every side during times of war. Special edition two-disc set including a thirty-minute documentary on the making of the film. Other Awards include the Palme D’Or at Cannes 2002. Cast includes Thomas Kretschmann.
